title.narrative: Planning For Better Quality Of Life In Datacenter Communities - Discovery Phase

description.narrative:
In September 2018, the Secretary-General Antonio Guterres said that the rate of sustainable development is too slow and that businesses need to play a major role in ensuring that it speeded up. Paragraph 67 of the 2030 Agenda and the Paragraph 133 of the New Urban Agenda both call for businesses to apply their creativity and innovation to solve sustainable development challenges. Sustainable Development Goal 17 encourages effective public-private partnerships and the Addis Ababa Action Agenda contains commitments at the highest political level to: “… develop policies and, where appropriate, strengthen regulatory frameworks to better align private sector incentives with public goals, including incentivizing the private sector to adopt sustainable practices, and foster long-term quality investment.”
The 2017 Report of the High-Level Independent Panel to Assess and Enhance the Effectiveness of UN-Habitat recognizes that most of the current investment in urban areas comes from the private sector and corporate interests and that the UN system must ensure that both public and private investment is subject to democratic oversight, protects the commons and respects human rights, and that it is aligned with the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development and the Sustainable Development Goals. Since the private sector plays such a large role in urban development, often with negative consequences, especially for excluded groups, the Panel recommends that UN-Habitat explore ways to encourage private sector actors to look at the unintended negative impacts of their investments and find ways to mitigate them.
UN-Habitat’s Strategic Plan 2020-2023 calls for a rethink regarding engagement with the private sector to leverage investments in sustainable urbanization and to promote more appropriate models of development. Particularly within Outcome 1.3 - Effective settlements growth and regeneration, and Outcome 2.3 - Frontier technologies and innovation, the Plan considers it important that UN-Habitat strengthen its engagement with the private sector, including ICT companies.
This project, then, provides a significant opportunity to work with a global business that is committed to aligning its business objectives with the Sustainable Development Goals, and specifically the Datacenters Community Development team which sees the sustainability of datacenter communities as a key element of its core business. In Microsoft’s own words ‘In over 10 years of building and managing our cloud infrastructure, we have come to understand that proactive urban planning is also a critical component to the long-term viability, growth, and social contribution of datacenters as social, environmental and economic assets to their host communities versus burdens on them.’
Microsoft’s has three datacenter community development objectives:
Building community partnerships that deliver economic, social, liveability and environmental benefits Improving the quality of conversations between community leaders, organizations, and Microsoft Developing a strong, technically-skilled, and diverse local workforce
The purpose of the project is to develop an urban planning model that can help Microsoft achieve these three objectives and make its datacenters more integrated with the local communities which are hosting them. UN-Habitat will use its 40+ years of experience of public participation, urban planning, governance and research to support these objectives.
Beyond Microsoft UN-Habitat will develop standards, guides and approaches that improve the sustainability of the industry as a whole, while retaining the economic benefits that come with datacenter development: the average U.S. large datacenter generates $7.8 million in annual wages and $77.7 million in construction phase wages (2016, US Chamber of Commerce).
In 2017 there were an estimated 8.6 million datacenters across the world (International Data Corporation), emitting about 2% of global greenhouse gas emissions (UNFCCC, 2016) and accounting for 17% of the ICT sector’s carbon footprint (Colocation America, 2018). With global IP traffic worldwide expected to treble between 2017 and 2022, datacenter development will keep growing and expand globally. With the industry’s growth, so will its waste and particularly e-waste. Datacenter servers have to be replaced every 3-5 years and disposed electronics worldwide already account for 2% of solid waste and 70% of toxic waste (World Economic Forum, 2019). In this context, beyond Microsoft there is a great opportunity for UN-Habitat to develop standards, guides and approaches that improve the sustainability of the whole industry.
